Posted: December 2, 2015
												So. Car Mechanic Simulator 2015. The year is almost over, and I have a good 100 hours on this game, so it's about time for a review.What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? It's definitely a very good game, it's informative in its own way, educational, and just plain fun, especially when you save up enough money and experience to expand your garage, get the paint shop, get the underground parking, and go to the auction house to buy wrecks you can fix up and sell for a profit.Of course, things are simplified a lot under the hood of each car you get to work on. I'm no mechanic, but I know enough of cars to have done maintenance on my own cars, and I have studied a lot of stuff for stories I write in which a character is an actual mechanic. There is in fact a funny thing about that; the game showed me painfully well how I got most of my knowledge about cars. It started in Dutch, as that is the language set on my laptop, and one of the first customer cars I got in showed a list that said there was a part that needed replacing. And I was all like; what the hell is that? So I saved and quit to menu, set the game language to English, started back up again, looked at the list, and went; Ohhh! Duh, a rubber bushing! Why didn't you just SAY so? I KNOW those! (And I know the name of that part mainly from watching YouTube videos of HotRod Magazine/HotRod Garage, and reading those kind of magazines - in English. For about 70% of the parts, I have NO clue what they are by the Dutch names alone)How simplified is it under the hood? Well, all cars have similar parts, for one. A front suspension has a crossmember, shocks, springs, a swaybar and end links, steering rack with inner and outer tie rods, upper and/or lower control arms, wheel knuckle housing, wheel hub, brake disk, pads, and a brake caliper. All but one or two cars come with a brake servo, and the newer models with an ABS pump and control unit. Brake lines? Nope. Brake fluid? Nope. A need to bleed the system after you rebuilt it? Nope.The engines? Let's stick with my favorite type of cars; the old ones. There's several classics that are all too recognizable; a 1957 Chevy Bel Air, a 1969 Ford Mustang, a 1968 Chevrolet Chevelle, a 1969 Dodge Charger. Of course they are not called that; the game has given each car its own brand and type. Big plus; they have actually taken the time to design logos and name badges that are on the cars, and they look good, too!But, the engines. Those four cars I mentioned all come with a carburated overhead-cam V8 engine. All parts are interchangeable, except for the two-carb intake manifold that comes on the Mustang. Have you bought a Chevelle and want to spruce it up a bit with a dual carburetor setup? Sorry, no can do, that dual-carb intake manifold is not an optional part for that car. Even when you take the V8 out of a Mustang and put it in the Chevelle, you can only put on the single-carb intake manifold. The only optional parts you can change on a car are the rims, and body parts if you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack.For the rest, though, it's good. Quite simplified, but with plenty of detail parts even so. Take apart one of those old V8's, and you find yourself with a box full of individual rocker arms and pushrods which you can take out one by one - and there's sixteen of them in one engine.There's one big drawback, though. You can't take the whole engine plus transmission out of the car in one big lump and put it on an engine stand to disassemble it, like almost any car restorer does; you have to disassemble, and reassemble it, in the car. And some parts you can only reach from underneath. Once you have gotten down to the engine block, it's; take out pistons, lift car, get under, remove oil pan (if you already hadn't), remove crankshaft caps, remove crankshaft, get out, lower car, remove engine block. Fix up or buy new one. Put in engine block, lift car, get under, put in crankshaft, put in crankshaft caps, get out, lower car, put in pistons, lift car, get under, put on oil pan and filter, get out, lower car, rebuild rest of the engine. That would be SO much easier if you could just take the whole thing out, put it on an engine stand, and disassemble/reassemble there.And the simplification shows. The plug wires are the only wires you'll find in the whole car. The detailing goes as far as to put individual clips on the air filter box/distributor cap you have to take off, but a wiring loom for all the electrics? Not there. Gaskets? Not there. There's a fuel filter, but fuel lines? Nope. Brake lines? Nope. And even on the most hashed-out rusty wreck of a 1957 Bel Air you buy at the auction house, ALL the bolts are always brand new. The rims and parts of the suspension/engine may be so rusted they are beyond repair, but they still come off with three turns of your wrench on the brand new bolts holding everything in place.The same goes for the fixing of the parts. You have a work table where you can fix a good number of the parts you take off a car. Butthe fixing process is; click. You managed to repair the part! Condition is now X%! Or; click. You failed to repair the part. Condition has decreased. (and it always decreases to a point so low you can't re-attempt to fix it again. So if you hash up a part, it's utterly broken and you need to buy a new one)Still, overall, it's a great game. After 100 hours I'm still not bored of it, even if I'm doing pretty much the same things over and over again. It just has that certain something about it that keeps drawing you in to play it more. There's just a few little things that could make it even better.- placing of the oil drain pan. That is SUCH a hit-and-miss, because you can't look upwards properly once you're moving that thing around. I end up just removing the oil pan and taking the $100 fine for oil cleanup, rather than to fiddle around with that drain and having it sit just a smidge too far to the left, right, front or back anyway.- disassembling/reassembling the engine outside of the car on an angine stand. If that could be implemented, it would be SUCH an improvement.- customizing of the cars. Currently, it's just visual with body parts and head/tail lights and bumpers, and rims, and only when you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack. If you were allowed to put different engines in different cars, or even do things like put that dual-carb intake on a single-carb V8 engine, that would make things a lot more fun. Also, speed parts would be nice. Take the tame little Pinto, yank out that four-banger engine, plop in a V8 with a high-lift cam, dual or triple carburetors and a turbo or a blower, and you suddenly have a much more interesting car.- graphics. Not the overall game graphics; those are pretty good as is. But some extra graphics for the cars? That would be a lot more fun. Take the Dodge Charger, give it a new paint job, and let us put on a bumblebee stripe around the rear end, for instance. Or racing stripes over the hood and trunk of the Chevelle. Or a spiffy flame-job. Hell yeah.- the test drive. Currently, there are in fact different engine sounds for the different cars, and some different driving characteristics. But the handling is atrocious, and the whole thing feels a bit... tacked on. Almost like it was an afterthought. There is massive potential for improvement there.- bodywork on the cars. At the moment, it's front bumper, headlights, hood, front fenders, doors, trunk lid, taillights, rear bumper. Not even windshields/rear windows/side windows (and everyone who ever restored an old car knows that the quarter panels/rear fenders and floor pans are 90% of the time the areas that need the most work). I can see a lot of potential for improvement there as well, the outer bodywork, and the interior as well. Allow us to put in leather bucket seats, for instance, or give the interior a different color than black.Do I recommend this game though? Hell yes!

Posted: July 31, 2015
												"An Investment in Automotive Education" While this game is not even close to a 100% representation of actual car functions or mechanic duties, I can honestly say that i know so much more about cars than i did before i started playing this. The first large chunk of this game will be occupied by repair jobs, where you will be required to find broken parts in the car and fix them. When enough experience and money is gathered, the real fun begins when you can purchase your own cars, then restore them and either sell them, or keep them for your own personal collection. The DLC for this game is fairly priced, but is not necessary to enjoy the game. Anyone who has an interest in cars, or just wants to learn more about cars should certainly pick up this game. It is fully worth the $19.99 price, but if its on sale, there is hardly an excuse to not give this a try.

Posted: December 8, 2015
												I've done engine/transmission swaps, factory and forged block and head rebuilds, and I'm currently in the process of attempting to make 800 rwhp on my '94 SC300 with a 2JZGTE VVTi/R154 swap.  Going with a GTX4088R, 2000cc Hi-Z Injector Dynamic injectors, dual 450 Walbro pumps, an OS Giken triple plate clutch with a hydraulic actuator conversion, Hypertune race intake manifold, a supra MK4 4.06 rear end, and many, many other mods.  In summary, I spend hours upon hours on forums reading about high HP builds and basic repair/maintenance on several different forum sites.  Even though my life is spent on cars outside of work, I can't get enough of this game because even with all of that experience, I still learn a thing or two each time that I play it.  Buy this game if you even have the slightest interest in automotive repair and modifications.

Posted: December 10, 2015
 Gameplay: 7/10 It gets tedious. You'd better hope you like unscrewing things (and then attempting to repair them, failing, buying new things, and screwing them back on). Then again, I'm sure being an automotive mechanic gets boring after a while, too. The cars all have the same basic components, as most cars do, but some have different layouts for more specific systems, like rear brake drums instead of discs or I4/I6/V8/V8OHV engines, etc. Despite this variation, after a few cars, you've seen it all. There's a lot of attention to detail, but even then, the game is not 100% accurate. If it was, though, I'd imagine it would be a lot more difficut. I'm glad that driving does not happen much in this game, because the driving mechanics were honestly not very good at all. Besides that, everything runs smoothly without any serious glitches. It performs as advertised. Graphics: 9/10 There isn't much to look at in this game, but what there is looks pretty nice. In other words, the textures and models all look great, but they mostly just sit there - no action. Plot: 0/10 It's a game about being a mechanic. What were you expecting, an epic tale of love, loss, and man's journey to find himself? There's no plot, you just fix cars for hours. I'm not really factoring plot into the overall rating, because that isn't the point of the game as I see it. Soundtrack: 4/10 One of this game's weakest points has to be the soundtrack. I know some mechanics, and I don't think many (if any at all) of them listen to EDM, and certainly not the same 5 songs in an endless loop. Now, you might think that it's fine. You'll just shut off the music and load up your own or whatever you usually do. Bad news:  YOU CAN'T SHUT IT OFF  (at least as far as I can tell). Now, it isn't  bad  EDM, it just gets super annoying. You must listen to the same songs over and over and over and over. Replay Value: 4/10 This game quickly becomes boring. There are only so many variations on cars and so many different tasks you can perfect performing. After a while, there's just no point in playing. The Trader Pack added the ability to buy cars at auction and restore them to keep or sell, but the only thing you can do with the money from selling cars is buy more cars or more car parts. It's very circular. It just feels like there's something missing at the upper level of this game. Overall: 60/100 I can't blame this game for being something I don't like. It's a simulation of being a mechanic, and I wasn't expecting much. So, as a game that simulates being an automotive repair specialist this game is probably a 90/100 (and stands pretty uncontested in its field). However, there's just about no replay value. There's no real reason to be satisfied with restoring even some of the nicest cars in the game because there's nothing to do with them after that, besides look at them and drive them around the generally pointless test track (the only textured driving course included with the game). The lack of replay value is what really ends up making this game kind of disappointing.  Suggestion:  What would make this game a 95/100 is a racing element: being able to buy performance-enhancing parts to upgrade your cars and then race for money. Despite its flaws, I'd say that Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is mostly worth the meager $19.99 it asks of your wallet.

												Hi! I'm not a huge car guy... the last vehicles I could work on was my 71 Ford Maverick and a 76 Chev 454, hehe. Just drive slow and only do left turns.  :DCMS 2015 is fun and cool! If you like sims, this is definitely worthwhile. In garage view, it seems better-suited for mouse and keyboard. Posted: June 24, 2015
												Vastly improved over CMS 2014. Graphics are much nicer and the engines/vehicles look much closer to their real life counterparts, though there are still a few mistakes. Wider variety of vehicles and a larger garage enables multiple jobs simultaenously.The ability to purchase cars at aution and restore them either for profit or your personal collection is very welcome. The only complaints I have about the auction house are that each car gets sent to your parking lot automatically and there is a set number of cars per auction. I do understand that the limited number of cars is more realistic but it is rather bothersome when I am looking for a specific car to work on. The issue with sending cars to the parking lot is understandable and would be more bearable if the loading times were lower.I also really liked the addition of diagnostic tools and a leveling system not based on cash. The only complaint in that department is that the repair skill maxes out at 90%. That is literally my one complaint about the new system. Everything else was a welcome change.The developer also seems to be pushing updates regularly (as of July, 2015) which is much appreciated. Several patches were already released since I purchased this game. More vehicles and tuning parts have also been added as optional DLC.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												There are quite a lot of pros and only a few cons to the game. Mind you, I will be comparing the older version to the newer version.Pros:-It is not very laggy: The biggest issue I had with the older version was that I set my game to the lowest video settings, but I still kept on lagging. This game takes that and throws it in the bin. With the same computer and same specs, the 2015 version was much more smoother than the 2014 version. I had at least 30fps all the way, whereas I would have 15-20fps on the 2014 version. -Interesting Campaign Mode: The one in CMS2014 was very controlled, you were given the same puzzle as everyone else who played the game. This gives you the choice to select the orders you want to take, and that is a game changer. No longer do you HAVE to do an order. You get to pick what you want to do. i.e I don't feel like fixing that guy's brakes, so I'll just select the order with the engine problems instead. This helps to make the game much more smoother and much more playable.-Much fewer glitches: I had a problem with CMS2014, and that was my order #43 glitched and I couldn't finish the order no matter how closely I followed the instructions. Since this is a newer game, we don't have as many glitches anymore. This game is being constantly updated, so it allows for improvement all the time. -Cool DLCs: We have had two DLCs come out by the time I am writing this review, Visual Tuning and Young Timer. Young Timer is free, with the nice little Fiat 500 lookalike. The Visual Tuning DLC does cost some money, however it is much more cheaper compared to the price tags on the other DLCs. Cons:-Time Consuming: Unless you are an absolute car bore who likes fixing the cars in this game like I do, you are not going to have a fun time. This is a simulator of what mechanics do on a daily basis, so ofcourse it is going to be time consuming, what did you expect? -Unlockables: In CMS2014, we had the OBD scanner as a tool since the beginning of the game. Why do we need to work on 10 cars maximum in order to unlock the tool that we had for a long time in the previous game? They could've let some tools remain like they were in the previous game. However, it does add for an interesting aspect to the gameplay, because now you get to work for the things you really want. Although that is interesting to me, it might not be to the other gamers. -Repair Uncertainty: Now again, unless you are a car enthusiast that finds these innovations interesting to the gameplay, you are probably not going to like the fact that there is a chance that the item you repair may not be fixed successfully. Overall, I think they did an excellent job with the new 2015 simulator. The new additional features are absolutely worth every single penny of that price tag. This new game completely demolishes the other older one, and I am not saying this because my CMS2014 Order #43 did not work. I genuinely believe this new game is a huge step forward from the previous one. I can now only imagine how much greater the 2016 version will be, definitely a rival to the upcoming Street Tuning Revolution. I am only joking, that game is a total in depth tuning game and it will take Red Dot Games a little while to catch up to that level, eventhough in my opinion it is very close. Then again, I have not played Street Tuning Evolution yet, so I can't tell the gap there might exist between the two games. CMS2016, that is a game definitely to look forward to.

Posted: June 6, 2015
												 Car Mechanic 2015 is a definite improvement from the 2014 version. There is a lot more detail in the work you do to the cars. I find myself not wanting to stop playing. I finish one job and I tell myself this is the last one I'm going to do today, then I start looking at the next job and find myself working on it till I finish. It is very addictive!  If you know nothing about cars, Car Mechanic 2015 will help you understand the basics of what is what on a car an where it can be found!I can't get enough of this game! I have had no issues with the game play at all! If you don't have it yet, get it, you'll love it!  Since I am a trained mechanic myself there are a few things that should be added to the next version, if there is going to be next version, like powers tools! Instead of using the ratchet sounds add in some power tool sound fx! Like the impact wrench and an air wratchet! These would make the game even more enjoyable! Also custom paint jobs woud be really cool as well! Something where you could have a set of custom designs the customer would like to put on their car and paint it in the paint booth! Even metallic colors would look great! Something for the designers to think about! I have a lot of ideas for future Car Mechanic Simulators! This game is well worth the money! Two thumbs up from me! Definitly on the top of my gaming list!

Posted: December 19, 2015
												Great way to kill time and learn the basics. However even though I know just the basics about a lawn-mower 2 stroke engine from a high school course -- I barely remember from 1987 I would say this game needs more reality to it. All the bolts require the same wrenches and there are no screw drivers that I have seen so far. There is nothing detailed about electrical lines. Nothing detailed about the distributer cap. You can put on wheels without being dinged point for not using the staring method to keep the tires from warping. There is no torque wrench, their is no scraping off an old gasket to replace with a new one. Shipping is instantaneous when there could easily be an online store you can ship from that the server populates that all people are trying to buy first -- in this case you would need to be able to put an order-in-as-next. Then the shipper should come by depending where in the country the item came from - 10 minutes - 2 hours, not days that wouldn't make a very good game unless they lowered the XP requirements for tools. The tools are too simple to use, nothing to hook up or see hooked up. You can drain the oil and do a compression test, which makes no sence like not using the star-torque to properly put on a tire. So more or less its a game for just to learn the names of the main parts of a vehicle, nothing really mechanic level -- or even close to. Yet I still have quite a bit of fun, I just pretend I scraped off a gasket and torquied and I just star-torque the lug-nuts back onto the tires when I put them back on.Devs: Please make some point loss for mess ups. Compressor test without oil, come on. -10 XP right there. How about when the driver takes the car to the back, they blow the engine costing you -100XP and $1000 and brings the car back with a seized cam rod and/or a piston because you forgot the oil. Also it would be nifty to have a boss that hangs around waiting for you to make a mistake and yells at you, but you can go into a fist mode and give him a temporary black eye for -10XP, MIGHT BE WORTH IT! Make this a $10.00 DLC for all this albet it sells fast!How about a DLC for weather so we an listen to lightning and rain and see some flashes out the window. An event where the outside tree is falling apart and if you arn't aware it crashes though and destroies your car in one of the bays? This way move to centre would be fun. A snow store causes your fingers to get really cold so you have to close a window and turn up the heat. I would pay $5 for this sort of enhancement DLC.Devs you have a great start here, why not a little extra realism for fun? All I do is pile up the XP and money, but nothing special is happening. Maybe there is a buy junk car sell for big bucks mode after I unlock the paintshop.But I like the game but no one should pay more than a copy on sale, the asking price is for a more realistic version. One more time I have to say this "Why - No - Gaskets?"l8r all

Posted: March 16
												Well, this is certainly a great sim. Perhaps not the most accurate ever in terms of mechanical detail (you'll probably notice a lot of chassis parts bolting into thin air when fixing or restoring vehicles) this game will definitely provide hours of entertainment. I won't lie, it's starts getting a little stale after a while, however, due to a lack of any pactical used for cars you've fixed or restored (aside from the tiny test track and drag strip you can run the car on). I think this game would be way better if they added more in terms of the business end of your repair shop, or in terms of the ability to enjoy your vehicles after all the work, besides selling them. Maybe add the ability to do interior customization work, and the ability to paint a car more than just a solid, single color. Sure, you can mod the game, but it's not like modding something like a Fallout or Elder Scrolls game. It seems like nobody actually makes pre-defined mods and the modding process itself seems pretty conveluded. Never the less, the game is enjoyable and can kill time with the best of them. Every aspect of the game that is present, is easy pick up, fun to play and intuitive. Now, Play Way, maybe you should make a racing game where you can import cars that have been restored or built in CMS15 and use them to race. That would give this game far more sustinance than the repeated grind of buying cars, fixing them, testing them, selling them.

Posted: November 2, 2015
												Around 6 hours into the game I've done about 8 cars.The game tends to hold your hand a lot, and everything is pretty straight forward. So far it has been more of a point and click simulator than a car mechanic simulator but it is still fairly entertaining.Not knowing anything about what goes on under the hood myself, the game has been somewhat educational in showing me where and what parts are that I've only seen on a repair/service bill. I do think with a little more time put into the game I might actually be able to go out to my car and identify them myself.For a simulator title, the game is very simplistic. Taking off parts is as simple as holding down a mouse button, and when you need to unbolt or unscrew something the same applies. When putting something back onto the car, you are provided with silhouettes of missing parts. This makes assembly fairly simple almost to the point of being too easy.Most of the cars have been more of the same, and I can see the game getting very repetitive quickly. The only difference in difficulty boils down to how extensively you will need to strip the car to get to the broken part. This becomes more of a chore than a difficulty factor. Speaking of broken parts, the only indication of this is rust. Parts do not have cracks etc. The only indication of wear on parts is rust. This makes most of the problems you fix linear and adds to repetition.All of this taken into account, you would think I would not recommend the game. However the game is fun in a zen repetition kind of way, and there is some novelty to the learning experience. My first maluch (old) car was more interesting since I had even less of an idea of where everything is, and I even left out some parts when putting the engine back together xDIf this is something that interests you, and the price is right, give it a try. But don't expect too much realism or much of a challenge.

Posted: October 27, 2015
												If you don't know what the pointy thing is at the midsection of your arm when you bend it or the soft squishy cushion like area at the top of your legs.. and you sometimes get them confused - you can still play this game.If you like to be led through all games regardless of genre and large open spaces cause you to reach for that old paper bag - you can still play this game.If you're looking for something a bit different after you've upgraded your weapons for the 'Nth' time and now you don't remember what it is or you're stuck on deciding whether your character's hair should flop to the right or left then give this game a shot. You learn real stuff about cars, instead of panicking and fleeing to the nearest dark corner when I lift the bonnet of my trusty Cruiser I can now point at a lot of the parts and name them. You can spend real time fixing up cars and then sell them on to earn money to buy more cars to sell or add to your personal collection.Also the devs regularly update this simulator, they take an active role in the community and cues from the suggestions made on how to improve the game.More fun than a dog with a box, dogs love boxes why is this?!

Posted: December 8, 2015
												I've done engine/transmission swaps, factory and forged block and head rebuilds, and I'm currently in the process of attempting to make 800 rwhp on my '94 SC300 with a 2JZGTE VVTi/R154 swap.  Going with a GTX4088R, 2000cc Hi-Z Injector Dynamic injectors, dual 450 Walbro pumps, an OS Giken triple plate clutch with a hydraulic actuator conversion, Hypertune race intake manifold, a supra MK4 4.06 rear end, and many, many other mods.  In summary, I spend hours upon hours on forums reading about high HP builds and basic repair/maintenance on several different forum sites.  Even though my life is spent on cars outside of work, I can't get enough of this game because even with all of that experience, I still learn a thing or two each time that I play it.  Buy this game if you even have the slightest interest in automotive repair and modifications.

Posted: December 10, 2015
 Gameplay: 7/10 It gets tedious. You'd better hope you like unscrewing things (and then attempting to repair them, failing, buying new things, and screwing them back on). Then again, I'm sure being an automotive mechanic gets boring after a while, too. The cars all have the same basic components, as most cars do, but some have different layouts for more specific systems, like rear brake drums instead of discs or I4/I6/V8/V8OHV engines, etc. Despite this variation, after a few cars, you've seen it all. There's a lot of attention to detail, but even then, the game is not 100% accurate. If it was, though, I'd imagine it would be a lot more difficut. I'm glad that driving does not happen much in this game, because the driving mechanics were honestly not very good at all. Besides that, everything runs smoothly without any serious glitches. It performs as advertised. Graphics: 9/10 There isn't much to look at in this game, but what there is looks pretty nice. In other words, the textures and models all look great, but they mostly just sit there - no action. Plot: 0/10 It's a game about being a mechanic. What were you expecting, an epic tale of love, loss, and man's journey to find himself? There's no plot, you just fix cars for hours. I'm not really factoring plot into the overall rating, because that isn't the point of the game as I see it. Soundtrack: 4/10 One of this game's weakest points has to be the soundtrack. I know some mechanics, and I don't think many (if any at all) of them listen to EDM, and certainly not the same 5 songs in an endless loop. Now, you might think that it's fine. You'll just shut off the music and load up your own or whatever you usually do. Bad news:  YOU CAN'T SHUT IT OFF  (at least as far as I can tell). Now, it isn't  bad  EDM, it just gets super annoying. You must listen to the same songs over and over and over and over. Replay Value: 4/10 This game quickly becomes boring. There are only so many variations on cars and so many different tasks you can perfect performing. After a while, there's just no point in playing. The Trader Pack added the ability to buy cars at auction and restore them to keep or sell, but the only thing you can do with the money from selling cars is buy more cars or more car parts. It's very circular. It just feels like there's something missing at the upper level of this game. Overall: 60/100 I can't blame this game for being something I don't like. It's a simulation of being a mechanic, and I wasn't expecting much. So, as a game that simulates being an automotive repair specialist this game is probably a 90/100 (and stands pretty uncontested in its field). However, there's just about no replay value. There's no real reason to be satisfied with restoring even some of the nicest cars in the game because there's nothing to do with them after that, besides look at them and drive them around the generally pointless test track (the only textured driving course included with the game). The lack of replay value is what really ends up making this game kind of disappointing.  Suggestion:  What would make this game a 95/100 is a racing element: being able to buy performance-enhancing parts to upgrade your cars and then race for money. Despite its flaws, I'd say that Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is mostly worth the meager $19.99 it asks of your wallet.

Posted: December 2, 2015
												So. Car Mechanic Simulator 2015. The year is almost over, and I have a good 100 hours on this game, so it's about time for a review.What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? It's definitely a very good game, it's informative in its own way, educational, and just plain fun, especially when you save up enough money and experience to expand your garage, get the paint shop, get the underground parking, and go to the auction house to buy wrecks you can fix up and sell for a profit.Of course, things are simplified a lot under the hood of each car you get to work on. I'm no mechanic, but I know enough of cars to have done maintenance on my own cars, and I have studied a lot of stuff for stories I write in which a character is an actual mechanic. There is in fact a funny thing about that; the game showed me painfully well how I got most of my knowledge about cars. It started in Dutch, as that is the language set on my laptop, and one of the first customer cars I got in showed a list that said there was a part that needed replacing. And I was all like; what the hell is that? So I saved and quit to menu, set the game language to English, started back up again, looked at the list, and went; Ohhh! Duh, a rubber bushing! Why didn't you just SAY so? I KNOW those! (And I know the name of that part mainly from watching YouTube videos of HotRod Magazine/HotRod Garage, and reading those kind of magazines - in English. For about 70% of the parts, I have NO clue what they are by the Dutch names alone)How simplified is it under the hood? Well, all cars have similar parts, for one. A front suspension has a crossmember, shocks, springs, a swaybar and end links, steering rack with inner and outer tie rods, upper and/or lower control arms, wheel knuckle housing, wheel hub, brake disk, pads, and a brake caliper. All but one or two cars come with a brake servo, and the newer models with an ABS pump and control unit. Brake lines? Nope. Brake fluid? Nope. A need to bleed the system after you rebuilt it? Nope.The engines? Let's stick with my favorite type of cars; the old ones. There's several classics that are all too recognizable; a 1957 Chevy Bel Air, a 1969 Ford Mustang, a 1968 Chevrolet Chevelle, a 1969 Dodge Charger. Of course they are not called that; the game has given each car its own brand and type. Big plus; they have actually taken the time to design logos and name badges that are on the cars, and they look good, too!But, the engines. Those four cars I mentioned all come with a carburated overhead-cam V8 engine. All parts are interchangeable, except for the two-carb intake manifold that comes on the Mustang. Have you bought a Chevelle and want to spruce it up a bit with a dual carburetor setup? Sorry, no can do, that dual-carb intake manifold is not an optional part for that car. Even when you take the V8 out of a Mustang and put it in the Chevelle, you can only put on the single-carb intake manifold. The only optional parts you can change on a car are the rims, and body parts if you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack.For the rest, though, it's good. Quite simplified, but with plenty of detail parts even so. Take apart one of those old V8's, and you find yourself with a box full of individual rocker arms and pushrods which you can take out one by one - and there's sixteen of them in one engine.There's one big drawback, though. You can't take the whole engine plus transmission out of the car in one big lump and put it on an engine stand to disassemble it, like almost any car restorer does; you have to disassemble, and reassemble it, in the car. And some parts you can only reach from underneath. Once you have gotten down to the engine block, it's; take out pistons, lift car, get under, remove oil pan (if you already hadn't), remove crankshaft caps, remove crankshaft, get out, lower car, remove engine block. Fix up or buy new one. Put in engine block, lift car, get under, put in crankshaft, put in crankshaft caps, get out, lower car, put in pistons, lift car, get under, put on oil pan and filter, get out, lower car, rebuild rest of the engine. That would be SO much easier if you could just take the whole thing out, put it on an engine stand, and disassemble/reassemble there.And the simplification shows. The plug wires are the only wires you'll find in the whole car. The detailing goes as far as to put individual clips on the air filter box/distributor cap you have to take off, but a wiring loom for all the electrics? Not there. Gaskets? Not there. There's a fuel filter, but fuel lines? Nope. Brake lines? Nope. And even on the most hashed-out rusty wreck of a 1957 Bel Air you buy at the auction house, ALL the bolts are always brand new. The rims and parts of the suspension/engine may be so rusted they are beyond repair, but they still come off with three turns of your wrench on the brand new bolts holding everything in place.The same goes for the fixing of the parts. You have a work table where you can fix a good number of the parts you take off a car. Butthe fixing process is; click. You managed to repair the part! Condition is now X%! Or; click. You failed to repair the part. Condition has decreased. (and it always decreases to a point so low you can't re-attempt to fix it again. So if you hash up a part, it's utterly broken and you need to buy a new one)Still, overall, it's a great game. After 100 hours I'm still not bored of it, even if I'm doing pretty much the same things over and over again. It just has that certain something about it that keeps drawing you in to play it more. There's just a few little things that could make it even better.- placing of the oil drain pan. That is SUCH a hit-and-miss, because you can't look upwards properly once you're moving that thing around. I end up just removing the oil pan and taking the $100 fine for oil cleanup, rather than to fiddle around with that drain and having it sit just a smidge too far to the left, right, front or back anyway.- disassembling/reassembling the engine outside of the car on an angine stand. If that could be implemented, it would be SUCH an improvement.- customizing of the cars. Currently, it's just visual with body parts and head/tail lights and bumpers, and rims, and only when you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack. If you were allowed to put different engines in different cars, or even do things like put that dual-carb intake on a single-carb V8 engine, that would make things a lot more fun. Also, speed parts would be nice. Take the tame little Pinto, yank out that four-banger engine, plop in a V8 with a high-lift cam, dual or triple carburetors and a turbo or a blower, and you suddenly have a much more interesting car.- graphics. Not the overall game graphics; those are pretty good as is. But some extra graphics for the cars? That would be a lot more fun. Take the Dodge Charger, give it a new paint job, and let us put on a bumblebee stripe around the rear end, for instance. Or racing stripes over the hood and trunk of the Chevelle. Or a spiffy flame-job. Hell yeah.- the test drive. Currently, there are in fact different engine sounds for the different cars, and some different driving characteristics. But the handling is atrocious, and the whole thing feels a bit... tacked on. Almost like it was an afterthought. There is massive potential for improvement there.- bodywork on the cars. At the moment, it's front bumper, headlights, hood, front fenders, doors, trunk lid, taillights, rear bumper. Not even windshields/rear windows/side windows (and everyone who ever restored an old car knows that the quarter panels/rear fenders and floor pans are 90% of the time the areas that need the most work). I can see a lot of potential for improvement there as well, the outer bodywork, and the interior as well. Allow us to put in leather bucket seats, for instance, or give the interior a different color than black.Do I recommend this game though? Hell yes!

Posted: August 23, 2016
												I was dubious about this game. There's a vast amount of Simulator titled games out there and from the title, this doesn't sound like it's one of the more interesting ones. In the end, I think it was a sale that enticed me in and I'm glad I did, there's gameplay to be had here.You don't necessarily get dropped in at the deep end, you start off only being able to access the more simple jobs. I know how a car works and how it's bolted together so unfortunately I can't comment on how easy this is for those totally new to it all. It's reasonably realistic though, so if you're picking it up you're learning something!The initial pace is a little slow and a bit 'grindy' in places. Once you've unlocked everything though there's a few ways you can play it. I've taken to buying cars at auction and completely rebuilding them to see how much profit is available in each model. There's a few other strategies I've not tried yet such as only replacing parts less than 80%.Eventually, you'll realise that all you're doing is giving the mouse some exercise as you're just clicking the same things over and over again. When that happens, you can switch the brain back on and take on a few customer jobs instead, requiring you to investigate things. I'm not sure how much life is left in the game, but I've had over 60 hours in it so far so I've gotten my moneys worth.

Posted: March 31
												Car Mechanic Simulator (henceforth CMS) 2015 is a distinct improvement over what was offered with CMS 2014. The fact that you can choose what jobs to accept or decline is very nice, especially as you are starting out and may not know where a particular problem might lie. However, where I think this game really shines is being able to buy a heap for cheap, gut it, repair what parts you are able, replace the rest, and sell it for a tidy profit. You may also elect to keep it for yourself, but there is little to do with it if you do, other than to simply look at it. My recommendation to any new players of the game is to do enough jobs to save up a bit of money, then start buying and fixing up cars from the auction. You can bet that the price of the car is going to double or triple in the auction house, and I would say to save up enough money to possibly double THAT amount before you start fixing things up. Until you really level up your repair skill (something I would definitely focus on fairly early on), you'll probably need to buy parts to replace all of the ones that you fail to repair. All of that aside, here is how I would evaluate the game:The Good:- Fixing up old cars and selling them is fantastic. This is where this game shines, and the enjoyment of this outweighs all of the negative points of this game put together. At the time of this review, I have clocked a little over 30 hours on the game, and I periodically return to it simply to do this. Although a little unrealistic, it's very satisfying to take something that's absolute garbage and get it into like-new condition, and there is a hefty bonus for selling a car that is in 100% condition.- Leveling up your skills as a mechanic is now separate from money, which you will be needing for the purchase of cars when you get tired of doing work orders.- Havng the garage means that you can hang onto a car that you really like, and it can be expanded with plenty of space for you to collect them all.- Fixing parts is free, but it has the possibility of breaking them, as well. This means that many jobs can be done quite cheaply, and this further increases the potential for profit in selling cars.- The game looks very nice and runs smoothly, at least on my computer.- The core gameplay of removing and replacing parts is executed well, and most things are pretty efficient, although it would be nice to have a side-by-side for your inventory and the shop.The Bad:- There is very little to do with cars once they are fixed up, other than sell them or send them to the garage. However, I don't really like driving or racing games, so this has little bearing on my opinion of the game.- Accessibility of parts is kind of an issue. Even if you are doing things in the most efficient way possible, you have to use the lift multiple times to get at every single part. The worst culprit by far is the crankshaft (and, by extension, the engine block). You have to use the lift once to remove the oil pan and the pieces keeping the crankshaft in place, another time to remove the pistons (and any other engine parts required to get at them), and once more to get the crankshaft out. Then, if you need to get at the engine block itself, it's a FOURTH go on the lift to get it out once the crankshaft has been removed. This is all a pretty minor gripe at the end of the day, and it may be fairly realistic, but it's still kind of annoying.- Even with the convenience of the PDA, which makes it so that you can buy parts without having to run back to your desk, the shop menu is separate from your inventory screen. This means that it can be cumbersome to buy a lot of parts to replace those that you have broken when fixing up an old junker.- Collecting oil requires you to be a sniper. Don't bother with it. Just pay the $100 cleanup fee.- Parts that you are repairing break quite often. When fully leveled, you have a 90% chance to repair a part, but you do not FULLY repair it. This means that you roll those dice multiple times per part. They really should've had a decrease in condition by a random amount if that 10% chance comes up, but instead, the thing is totally borked. So if you have a part that is in poor condition so that you need to hit "repair" 4 times to get it fully to 100%, then you actually have a chance that is 90%*90%*90%*90%, or about 66% chance of getting it fully repaired and 34% chance of breaking it entirely and paying to replace it. That may not sound bad, but that is what it is like when you're at max level. - DLC. Gross. Well, it's not AWFUL, but here's the thing: the "Gold" version of this game only includes some of the DLC. Most of the rest of it adds actual brand name vehicles to the lineup. So, since they have to pay to use those brands, it makes some sense. Even so, it leaves a bitter taste in my mouth to buy the Gold version and not even get the majority of the DLC.The Ugly:- The game actually looks very nice on the whole, but the textures for new parts sometimes doesn't say "shiny chrome" so much as it does "plastic thing painted to look like shiny chrome."- Some of the paint colors are pretty awful.... well, just like with real-life cars, truthfully. Many of them are quite nice, but it seems like you're more likely to wind up with something pretty ugly. You can paint them a new color, but you really can't preview a car's color very well in the paint shop without paying to have it painted, which means that tweaking that color can get kinda expensive.

Posted: August 12, 2016
Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 (CMS 15) is exactly what is sounds like: a car mechanic simulator. The player takes the role of a mechanic in your very own garage. As you build up a good reputation and learn more, you get to work on harder, more complex vehicles. You are given hints early on to help you determine exactly what parts to fix or replace, but soon those nice yellow outlines will disappear, and you're on your own. Cars get nicer, and so do your payouts.Car Mechanic Sim is literally all I hoped it to be. I wanted to learn more about how cars come together, and it did the job perfectly for me. While it's not a 100% accurate simulation, the game does a good job of giving you the gist of certain aspects of how a car works. Before playing CMS15, I wouldn't have known how suspension even works in cars. I really like working on older cars, such as muscle cars and other little classic cars, because of how different they are from modern designs, especially the engines and the suspension setups.ProsGood basic learning toolLots of inexpensive DLCs to expand the gameplay (licensed brands, tuning options)Good array of cars parodied from real-world vehicles.ConsNot a full car simulation! It's a mechanic sim!Gets progressively more difficult (could be interpreted either way really, just putting it in the cons because it has more weight as a con) The gameplay is a bit repetitive after a while. You may like to try the challenge mode to mix things up a bit!Final Thoughts:CMS is a good way to pass time and learn something while doing it!Rating: 9.0/10This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

Posted: February 29, 2016
												Yes my review says I DO NOT recommend this game and it is not because it is bad. It is amazing as it really does simulate being a mechanic, its tedious, repetetive and will sometimes get frustrating. Now having said that it is a lot simpler than being an actual mechanic as it does not go into extreme detail. It is a very simplified game, and this brings me to what it really is. A game. This lies somewhere in the middle of being a game and a simulator, its way too repetitive to be any kind of fun as a game but it doesn't quite get to the detail to make it fun as a simulator.So in summary Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 gives a very good feeling of what it is like to BE a mechanic but is terrible at simulating working on cars. It is a confused game and is not really a simulator. I really did expect more.I am not saying don't buy it, just do a little more research first so you know what your getting into.

												I like it for what it is.  A simplified instructional simulation on how cars are basically put together.  It's got a bit of a learning curve but once you've done a couple of brake jobs you can knock it out in no time.  You can upscale the learning by then looking at your own car and try and identify the parts. I presume alot of the content has pantenting and tradmarking so modern cars aren't readily available.  I probably need to check out the mods to find different cars.

Posted: March 24
												This game is a massive improvement to CMS14 in every meaningful way, and will help to quickly fill in the gaps to your car knowledge. As with any simulator, there is only so far that you can go to make it feel like the real thing, but in terms of interactive, consumer-grade media, this is probably the best thing on the market right now.The game can get a little repetitive at times, but I'm sure being an actual car mechanic gets a little repetetive too, particularly if you were to specialize in a limited field (like Japanese import transmissions, etc.). This game allows you to work on all aspects of a car, and for the most part, you can strip the cars down to the bone. The upgrade system is kind of a grind, but overall the pacing feels right. If you start a traditional game, the vehicles will have lists of the parts that need replacing, which can be highlighted on the car and identified easily. Over time, the lists will start to identify fewer and fewer parts, and force you to have to search for them and inspect manually. The projects themselves also become increasingly complicated. This system feels like it's rewarding your learning, and it's an empowering feeling. In general I detest the business model in games nowadays -- especially from major studios/publishers -- that basically forces you to buy 'modules' in the form of DLC that should have been included at launch by default. This game does that, but doesn't feel like you're being robbed either. You may only be interested in learning the SUV/Truck or an old Mini, so in that sense it works and makes sense here. In this setting. it doesn't subtract from the gameplay or force you to purchase the ending/continuation of the story, so I can't knock it too much.In a relatively limited timeframe, you will probably be able to name every single part on a car, regardless of the engine/vehicle type. If that is your goal, you can't miss this one. Can't wait to see what they do with the next iteration.

Posted: February 25, 2016
												I love this game. It's a great game to unwind to, zone out, and just get lost while listening to music, or hell, even the game's really cool soundtrack.If you're new to cars, or have an intermediate proficiency, then you really will probably learn something from it. A few folks complain about it not being accurate or realistic, and it isn't, but it gives you a very general overview of how cars are put together and how to take them apart. If you're at all a gearhead, or at all enjoy tinkering, puzzle games, or relaxing games, then this is for you.

Posted: June 17, 2015
												Since this trend of what I call "blue collar gaming," I've been reluctant to partake.  On a whim (and after reading other reviews), however, I picked this one up and was blown away.  Not only is the game fun, but I've learned a ton about the basics of automobiles and how they work.  Coming from this as a complete novice (the equivalent of "where's the crankshaft, in the glove box?), I went from having to dismantle pretty much the entire car every repair to figuring out exactly what I needed to for each job =)One thing I will add, however -- I've learned on Steam to pay attention to how developers are supporting their games, especially when they first hit the store.  If you check out the news on this game you'll see how responsive Red Dot has been -- it's insane!  Almost weekly (and sometimes daily) there's a bug fix, a mechanical improvement, DLC ... very, very impressed.If you think you'd have fun learning how to wrench on virtual cars, trust me and get this one!

Posted: July 29, 2016
												This is a pretty entertaining game, even for a light/heavy line auto technician who does the real life stuff. Its great to pass the time with, learn a little (for the average individual who doesn't do this kind of work), and enjoy a game for those who have the automotive passion. Most average players won't notice the mistakes, but it's understandbly not 100% realistic. A couple examples are: The "power steering pump" looks exactly like an A/C compressor on most models. Also, I had no idea a belt driven radiator fan could bolt up to nothing with four bolts in FRONT of the radiator. And lastly, coming from someone who does this kind work in reality......don't spend an hour with frustration on how to drop the fuel tank or try to remove the back seat in a car to change the fuel pump in the top of the tank. You know, the usual, real life step you would have to take. Because none of that works or is apparently needed. You can apparently just remove the fuel pump in the tank that's buried in the car. Makes no sense. Real world thinking screwed me there for a bit.Anyway, game doesn't have any bugs. No glitches or issues with playability.All in all, not too bad of a game. I enjoy it.

Posted: June 9, 2016
												So much, yet so little..,First of all, I thoroughly enjoy this game, I really do. I find myself perpetually visiting the site in order to see what new features and DLCs are available to satisfy this newly created obsession of putting wonderful machines together in different ways that I could never hope to afford on a garbage man's salary.When I first purchased Car Mechanic Simulator 2015, it was one of those titles on my wishlist that I'd hoped would finally give me enough of that car-mod junkie fix I was looking for. My feelings might be mixed on that one though. I played a game called Street Legal Racing (Redline) for a while that allowed you to put some cars together, but was extremely limited without the plethora of User Mods available out there (unfortunately, they cause the game to crash as often as -insert expletive here). What it did do right however, was the customizeability, and a nod to the racing genre if you felt like pursuing the in-game "game".Ok, let's start with what CMS 2015 is not. It is not a "Need For Speed" clone, and that is Ok. As titillating as the prospect of racing a hard worked, hard earned car is around a fictional Nürburgring facsimile with 15 sirens blaring in the background, I am of the mind that even with a AAA budget, you can either do one thing or the other very well but not both. CMS 2015 focuses on the simulatory aspects of building up your virtual baby with a level of detail that pleases and surprises.You start out with a workshop and some car repair jobs to choose from. As you progress, you gain some cash and leveling points that you can spend on equipment and such. Without delving into too many details so as to stay on point, you get to purchase or fix different components ranging from the suspension to the engine and really get into the "nuts and bolts" of things. After 20 or so hours and a real sense of accomplishment, I felt myself wishing that I could get even further detail into the parts I was dealing with. I was satisfied with changing things like cylinder heads and screwing on the bolts, but I kind of felt like "where is the head gasket?" That pesky thing that once caused me an overdraft and a scolding from my manager for coming in late. Another thing I desperately wanted, was to take Mr. Bean's car and drop some American V8 muscle in it with 21 inch rims and a boeing wing for downforce. Unfortunately and inexplicably, you can't! It seems to me that the foundations of the game are solid enough to support this though and I do really hope to see something like this very soon. In conclusion, the aspects that are included are very well polished. The assortment of cars work as unique puzzles that need specific pieces to fit in the right order and give you a greater appreciation than the sum of their parts. Yet, more detailed problems can be fleshed out to create greater challenges, as well as interesting combinations that could increase the longevity of the game (not to mention better custom modding) by leaps and bounds.Either way, I want more!

Posted: August 23, 2016
												I was dubious about this game. There's a vast amount of Simulator titled games out there and from the title, this doesn't sound like it's one of the more interesting ones. In the end, I think it was a sale that enticed me in and I'm glad I did, there's gameplay to be had here.You don't necessarily get dropped in at the deep end, you start off only being able to access the more simple jobs. I know how a car works and how it's bolted together so unfortunately I can't comment on how easy this is for those totally new to it all. It's reasonably realistic though, so if you're picking it up you're learning something!The initial pace is a little slow and a bit 'grindy' in places. Once you've unlocked everything though there's a few ways you can play it. I've taken to buying cars at auction and completely rebuilding them to see how much profit is available in each model. There's a few other strategies I've not tried yet such as only replacing parts less than 80%.Eventually, you'll realise that all you're doing is giving the mouse some exercise as you're just clicking the same things over and over again. When that happens, you can switch the brain back on and take on a few customer jobs instead, requiring you to investigate things. I'm not sure how much life is left in the game, but I've had over 60 hours in it so far so I've gotten my moneys worth.

Posted: March 31
												Car Mechanic Simulator (henceforth CMS) 2015 is a distinct improvement over what was offered with CMS 2014. The fact that you can choose what jobs to accept or decline is very nice, especially as you are starting out and may not know where a particular problem might lie. However, where I think this game really shines is being able to buy a heap for cheap, gut it, repair what parts you are able, replace the rest, and sell it for a tidy profit. You may also elect to keep it for yourself, but there is little to do with it if you do, other than to simply look at it. My recommendation to any new players of the game is to do enough jobs to save up a bit of money, then start buying and fixing up cars from the auction. You can bet that the price of the car is going to double or triple in the auction house, and I would say to save up enough money to possibly double THAT amount before you start fixing things up. Until you really level up your repair skill (something I would definitely focus on fairly early on), you'll probably need to buy parts to replace all of the ones that you fail to repair. All of that aside, here is how I would evaluate the game:The Good:- Fixing up old cars and selling them is fantastic. This is where this game shines, and the enjoyment of this outweighs all of the negative points of this game put together. At the time of this review, I have clocked a little over 30 hours on the game, and I periodically return to it simply to do this. Although a little unrealistic, it's very satisfying to take something that's absolute garbage and get it into like-new condition, and there is a hefty bonus for selling a car that is in 100% condition.- Leveling up your skills as a mechanic is now separate from money, which you will be needing for the purchase of cars when you get tired of doing work orders.- Havng the garage means that you can hang onto a car that you really like, and it can be expanded with plenty of space for you to collect them all.- Fixing parts is free, but it has the possibility of breaking them, as well. This means that many jobs can be done quite cheaply, and this further increases the potential for profit in selling cars.- The game looks very nice and runs smoothly, at least on my computer.- The core gameplay of removing and replacing parts is executed well, and most things are pretty efficient, although it would be nice to have a side-by-side for your inventory and the shop.The Bad:- There is very little to do with cars once they are fixed up, other than sell them or send them to the garage. However, I don't really like driving or racing games, so this has little bearing on my opinion of the game.- Accessibility of parts is kind of an issue. Even if you are doing things in the most efficient way possible, you have to use the lift multiple times to get at every single part. The worst culprit by far is the crankshaft (and, by extension, the engine block). You have to use the lift once to remove the oil pan and the pieces keeping the crankshaft in place, another time to remove the pistons (and any other engine parts required to get at them), and once more to get the crankshaft out. Then, if you need to get at the engine block itself, it's a FOURTH go on the lift to get it out once the crankshaft has been removed. This is all a pretty minor gripe at the end of the day, and it may be fairly realistic, but it's still kind of annoying.- Even with the convenience of the PDA, which makes it so that you can buy parts without having to run back to your desk, the shop menu is separate from your inventory screen. This means that it can be cumbersome to buy a lot of parts to replace those that you have broken when fixing up an old junker.- Collecting oil requires you to be a sniper. Don't bother with it. Just pay the $100 cleanup fee.- Parts that you are repairing break quite often. When fully leveled, you have a 90% chance to repair a part, but you do not FULLY repair it. This means that you roll those dice multiple times per part. They really should've had a decrease in condition by a random amount if that 10% chance comes up, but instead, the thing is totally borked. So if you have a part that is in poor condition so that you need to hit "repair" 4 times to get it fully to 100%, then you actually have a chance that is 90%*90%*90%*90%, or about 66% chance of getting it fully repaired and 34% chance of breaking it entirely and paying to replace it. That may not sound bad, but that is what it is like when you're at max level. - DLC. Gross. Well, it's not AWFUL, but here's the thing: the "Gold" version of this game only includes some of the DLC. Most of the rest of it adds actual brand name vehicles to the lineup. So, since they have to pay to use those brands, it makes some sense. Even so, it leaves a bitter taste in my mouth to buy the Gold version and not even get the majority of the DLC.The Ugly:- The game actually looks very nice on the whole, but the textures for new parts sometimes doesn't say "shiny chrome" so much as it does "plastic thing painted to look like shiny chrome."- Some of the paint colors are pretty awful.... well, just like with real-life cars, truthfully. Many of them are quite nice, but it seems like you're more likely to wind up with something pretty ugly. You can paint them a new color, but you really can't preview a car's color very well in the paint shop without paying to have it painted, which means that tweaking that color can get kinda expensive.

Posted: October 29, 2016
												As someone who really works on cars, I'd say this is a failry accurate mechanic sim without the grazed knuckles and frustration of hard to get to bolts.Very similar to games such as Gearhead Garage and Street Legal, this game puts you in charge of your own workshop. You make money fixing customers cars which you can then spend on buying cars at auction. The auction cars always need some work, when the work is complete you can either add the car to your garage, or sell it for a profit.I am restoring a DeLorean in real life so I also grabbed the DeLorean DLC. It's pretty accurate, although some things in the engine bay are in the wrong place and the DeLorean in this game has a power steering pump instead of an A/C unit, but I understand this is probably a limitation of the game engine. It did feel weird taking the mix unit and intake manifold off to inspect the Valley of Death as I have done on my own DeLorean.I've had hours of fun, the only downside to the game is it can get repetitive. quite a lot of the customer jobs are big jobs such as rebuilding the entire front and back suspension system, which is time consuming and monotonous. Having said that, life as a real mechanic would be very similar. There is also not much you can do with your own cars once they have been rebuilt, apart from sit in them or take them around a test track.Overall I'd recommend this game to anyone who has an interest in pulling cars and engines to bits and at the moment this is probably THE best game on the market for anyone wanting a modern Gearhead Garage clone.

Posted: July 4, 2016
												I'm no expert when it comes to cars but this game has got my attention, I bought this game not only to have fun but to learn car parts as well. The game is really fun (seriously), especially if you buy the Performance DLC because you can modify your own car even more like swapping engines! Unfortunately there's no tutorial, at least for the control. You won't be guided what to do to fix the car, you'll be given list of parts that needs to be replaced and that's it (I even search Google Image to find the location of the part xD). If you gain enough XP there will be more challenges, like you need to find the broken parts yourself. Soon you'll get tools like OBD Scanner to help you examine broken parts faster and more easily.---------------------------The game's pretty small though, unlike game like Euro Truck Simulator 2 where you can name you company, hire staff, travel between countries. This game only let you work inside a garage alone, so this game can be boring after you play the game for a while. Well you can test cars in a test track, buy your own personal car, and have a drag race but that's basically it. Even so, to purchase your own car, you need to get a parking lot, which require lots of XP to be able to purchase it.---------------------------You should purchase this game if you're interested in cars, because believe me, you'll be fixing cars all day long and if you're not into it you'll ditch the game right away.

Posted: November 19, 2016
												ProsThe SimulatorHow to start?The Simulator is incredible ... Many pieces to work with, several types of defects, several ways to solve unique problems ...Simply incredible, many of the rules used in the maintenance and reform of automobiles appears in this simulator, not to call the game ... at immersion level and incredible the game "clean" without DLCs is already greatDLC'sAll very well done, with parts, components and unique builds for each car, now these dlc's with official marks make the simulator even more incredible.My favorites are the Performance DLC and Visual Tunning left a lot of memory for the classic SLRR MWM, and the wordless delorean even with the effect of time travel ... and very fun to point the car to a wall and it simply disappears without crashing. ..ConsWell not everything is perfect, the game sins in a few basic things ... the repetitiveness, the soundtrack, and the total lack of races.RepeatabilityThis was a little impossible to escape, after all, work is repetitive ... so there's no wayThe soundtrackCould have more songs, besides electronics, prepare a hot hod listening to electronics does not match the moment.RacingAs stated by the developers themselves on the facebook page ... "The focus of the game is not racing, but only maintenance, if you want clues, wait for the community to develop" (Not exactly with those words), if you prepare the car do not Take a turn on a curved track or leave the garage for a few laps in the neighborhood ... and a shame.DLC'sCustom PaintsPaint modern cars prepared or old hotrods, deserve some decals, a black hood, banners and etc ... could there be such a DLC ...SuspensionOk, the producer gave wheels, Tires ... but how about a suspension of races ?, or maybe an offroad suspension, or even a suspension for street races, it would be very interesting to be able to prepare cars like thisVisual tunning (In the photo has Spoiler in the DLC does not)A DLC that has the name of Visual Tunning and does not have bolder Escapes, bodykits nor the simplest and most basic Spoilers !, Spoilers! Do not put in a photo what does not come with the product ...InteriorsIf it is possible to have tunning in the game, do not think that it lacks the substitution of seats, steering wheel and things like ... nor is it necessary to put speakers in the car ... but to be able to use banks Sparco for example would be good ...ConclusionThe Simulator is incredible, yes ... are they planning a 2017? Maybe, but keeping the 2015 or Creating a 2017, add more things more options, the players thank you.Final grade(9,5 / 10)

Posted: January 5, 2016
												Not what i was expecting from the pictures and the trailers they advertize the whole game to be.... its very fun and addicting, i still play it but hope theres ALOT more to come. Theres not a whole lot to customization even with ALL the DLC. They advertize superchargers and turbochargers and coming soon DLC for engine mods from last year thats not out. they have maybe 3 vehicles that come turbo'd in the game, but you cannot add a turbo to other vehicles with those same engines.  you can't engine swap v8's into RWD 6cyl/4cyl cars, theres no ride height/lift kits for the ONE truck (2 versions just the REX has black trim around windows and different headlights/tailights) and ONE suv that comes in the Truck&SUV DLC package. theres maybe 2 options for body parts on a majority of the vehicles (one being stock/other is a "custom" bumper, headlight, hood etc..). the only way to change wheel/tire size, power and RPM limits, or weight of a vehicle is by going in and modding the actual files in the game (which they encourage you do) in which if you do it wrong you'll wreck the game, instead of coming out with a Dyno/Tuning room. It shows you can remove the tires from the wheels and put different tire types/sizes, you can't. I was hoping to see customization for suspention and ride heights as that would be huge for customizing the look and drivability of vehicles in the showroom or on the test track. All in all i would recommend this game knowing all of these as its still addicting and relaxing game, It just seems Incomplete to me. I hope they have ALOT more coming for this game.

Posted: September 23, 2016
												So the past couple days, as of this writing, I changed my oil, replaced the oil filter, replaced the brake pads and bled the clutch and topped off the tire pressure on my car.That being said after all that I was in the mood to finally give this game a shot but I can't really call this a simulator because I wasn't busting my knuckles on things, getting my hands covered in something that probably causes a cancer known to the state of California, losing tiny parts and yelling curse words, that would make even a sailor blush, for all my neighbors to hear.I'm pretty sure anyone who has worked on a car knows what I'm talking about; if you really want to get to know what a person is really like inside have them work on a car.On a serious note though I think the game is pretty cool and refreshingly different but as someone who works on his own cars I have to say this is more of a puzzle game than a simulator but still intriguing if you're interested in the internal workings of a car; I can see how this game would be super interesting for someone who hasn't much experience working on cars.Maybe I just haven't got far enough into the game yet but the cars seem rather barren and the engine compartment isn't a dizzing array of hoses, pipes and wires like in real life.Also why is oil disposal $100? Maybe it's just where I live where you can dispose of oil for free at any auto parts store or a county waste site, but it's probably just one of those gameplay balancing things.One thing I do like is being able to go on the computer ingame and then finding and ordering parts from fictitious websites. It's not a biggie but a nice touch I think.My only real complaint is the music which is pretty much, so far, nothing but the wub wub wub kind of dubstep.Being a car mechanic themed game I would expect something a little more blue collar like rock or blues but that's okay; I opted to turn the music off and listen to my own music so it's not that big of a deal.One suggestion for the developers: Make a more detailed version of this game in VR with the Vive controllers. That would be awesome!

Posted: September 13, 2016
												Overall I really enjoy this game. I really feel like this is a spiritual successor to a much older game that some car enthusiasts might be familiar with ("Gearhead Garage"). There are a lot of welcome improvements over the 2014 version of the game such as the ability to buy cars from the auction and sell them. The variety of cars is good and I like how there is an actual variety of how you assemble the vehicles. The graphics are pretty nice. Some of the game modes such as the test track and the paint booth seem a little underdeveloped in my opinion (as in the steering is a little difficult and the paint booth is pretty simplistic in terms of color choice.) The DLCs are pretty reasonably priced for the content in them. The only two things that bother me to any extent in the game is that you have to put a LOT of time into the game before you are able to access the auction block. I feel like the real highlight of the game is the ability to buy cars in various condition at the auction and then fix them up to sell them. Along with the auction sequence comes my second issue with the game: you should be able to put the car up for auction as opposed to outright selling it, and the work order screen should have some information on how much of a total monetary and time investment you have in the car.  With those things said, I don't think that they interfere with my enjoyment of the game to the extent that I would quit playing it or that I wouldn't recommend it.I bought the game as a bundle with a lot of its DLC included. I would buy it again. I would recommend it to others that are interested in cars and simulation games.

Posted: May 11, 2016
Highly recommended for fans of motors, cars, or puzzle games.Yeah. That's what I'd call this at the end of the day--a puzzle game.Generally it goes like this: Someone comes in with a car and tells you what's wrong with it--or rather as much as they can. In the beginning this is usually a description like "Loud exhaust" or "Strange knocking sounds", and then a full list of parts. You then go buy those parts for the customer, go in, and find and replace them. Eventually however the game stops holding your hand. You're given the description of the problem, and a list of the NUMBER of parts that need replacing, but you're not told which ones they are. You have to go in and manually inspect the engine, or the exhaust, or the transmission, and you have to diagnose those problems yourself. It's challenging, it's fun, and it's all the great parts about working on a car with none of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.It's a really cool game, and the DLC just makes it even cooler, with the addition of aftermarket parts, engine swaps, and new cars to play with. The DLC are VERY appropriately priced as well, each one adding just enough content to justify their price without feeling like a ripoff or a total steal.The only thing I can possibly complain about is the god forsaken soundtrack. It's ♥♥♥♥ing awesome, but there are literally like... 4 or 5 songs that just play over and over--I suppose it's a rather realistic simulation of listening to the radio, but without any ads or DJs. Thankfully though, you can mute that♥♥♥♥♥♥ So when you get tired of the music--and you will--just go put on some hair metal and get back to thrashing.

Posted: August 12, 2016
Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 (CMS 15) is exactly what is sounds like: a car mechanic simulator. The player takes the role of a mechanic in your very own garage. As you build up a good reputation and learn more, you get to work on harder, more complex vehicles. You are given hints early on to help you determine exactly what parts to fix or replace, but soon those nice yellow outlines will disappear, and you're on your own. Cars get nicer, and so do your payouts.Car Mechanic Sim is literally all I hoped it to be. I wanted to learn more about how cars come together, and it did the job perfectly for me. While it's not a 100% accurate simulation, the game does a good job of giving you the gist of certain aspects of how a car works. Before playing CMS15, I wouldn't have known how suspension even works in cars. I really like working on older cars, such as muscle cars and other little classic cars, because of how different they are from modern designs, especially the engines and the suspension setups.ProsGood basic learning toolLots of inexpensive DLCs to expand the gameplay (licensed brands, tuning options)Good array of cars parodied from real-world vehicles.ConsNot a full car simulation! It's a mechanic sim!Gets progressively more difficult (could be interpreted either way really, just putting it in the cons because it has more weight as a con) The gameplay is a bit repetitive after a while. You may like to try the challenge mode to mix things up a bit!Final Thoughts:CMS is a good way to pass time and learn something while doing it!Rating: 9.0/10This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.
