Posted: April 15, 2016
												This game is literally working in a car repair shop withhout oil and mess all over your hands, without missing nuts and bolts and of course, being in the comfort of your home. The game becomes more fun when you can buy your own cars and fix them up, however eventually you would have fixed so many cars, that it would be a bit boring after some time. The dev's have been releasing DLC's frequently though, so that we have more cars to mingle around with. Recently the Mercedes DLC came out, now THAT was a suprise. here are the Pro's and Con's about this game.Pro's-Wide variety of cars-Huge amount of customization for the garages-Bodykits and new rims if you get the DLC-Nice and simple auction system-Upgrades that make it more convenient in-game, for eg. faster un-bolting times, portable tablet for easy purchase of parts etcCon's-Bad inventory organising and sorting-Small and confined area to test your cars-Interior of cars are never damaged, torn or worn-Strange driving physics Overall I feel this is a great game for car enthusiasts and is not over complicated for those who are still extending their knowlage of cars, this game runs very smoothly on my MacBook Air and should do well on a PC running core i5 and has 4GB of ram.

Posted: September 13, 2016
												Overall I really enjoy this game. I really feel like this is a spiritual successor to a much older game that some car enthusiasts might be familiar with ("Gearhead Garage"). There are a lot of welcome improvements over the 2014 version of the game such as the ability to buy cars from the auction and sell them. The variety of cars is good and I like how there is an actual variety of how you assemble the vehicles. The graphics are pretty nice. Some of the game modes such as the test track and the paint booth seem a little underdeveloped in my opinion (as in the steering is a little difficult and the paint booth is pretty simplistic in terms of color choice.) The DLCs are pretty reasonably priced for the content in them. The only two things that bother me to any extent in the game is that you have to put a LOT of time into the game before you are able to access the auction block. I feel like the real highlight of the game is the ability to buy cars in various condition at the auction and then fix them up to sell them. Along with the auction sequence comes my second issue with the game: you should be able to put the car up for auction as opposed to outright selling it, and the work order screen should have some information on how much of a total monetary and time investment you have in the car.  With those things said, I don't think that they interfere with my enjoyment of the game to the extent that I would quit playing it or that I wouldn't recommend it.I bought the game as a bundle with a lot of its DLC included. I would buy it again. I would recommend it to others that are interested in cars and simulation games.

Posted: September 15, 2016
												Fun game if you have an interest in cars and car mechanics.The game looks and feels great - you never feel like you're battling a crummy UI or awkward camera. Stripping parts is neither fast nor slow - gives the sense that you're tearing a machine down, rather than just automagically removing everything - this is always going to be hard to balance just right but I think the game gets as close as it needs to.The only thing I've found that I wish I could do is make recommendations to the customer. As it is every job has a minimum wear level - so any parts below a certain wear need to be replaced.  A good example of where I'd like this to work differently is if I'm doing a brake job and am replacing 3 brake pads - in reality this would never happen, you'd replace them all, even if the 4th isn't particularly worn.I don't really rate the driving aspects of the game - but it's not why I bought it so I can overlook it, and once you get the test path you don't really need to drive the cars anyway. If you're looking for a game more like Street Legal Racing then you might be dissapointed though.

												In this game I am the mechanic you fear in real life. I just swap decent parts from one side of the car to the other replacing the bad parts with the decent ones then putting the bad parts on the side that had the decent ones. I tried to send out an incomplete car but the developers were one step ahead of me. I don't know why I do this, a rubber bushing is like $12 in this game and takes 2 seconds to get but no I'll just disassemble half the car for a half hour to find a bushing that meets the minimum quality required for this car and swap them out. I am a horrible person. I do like this game alot I just have a personal problem.I think this could be fixed by giving the car an starting percentage of quality by averaging all the parts on the car and you have to send the car out better than when it arrives.My biggest complaint about games is the lack of music selection, but I understand theres liscensing fees and stuff like that plus royalties so I can let it slide. Posted: September 23, 2016
												So the past couple days, as of this writing, I changed my oil, replaced the oil filter, replaced the brake pads and bled the clutch and topped off the tire pressure on my car.That being said after all that I was in the mood to finally give this game a shot but I can't really call this a simulator because I wasn't busting my knuckles on things, getting my hands covered in something that probably causes a cancer known to the state of California, losing tiny parts and yelling curse words, that would make even a sailor blush, for all my neighbors to hear.I'm pretty sure anyone who has worked on a car knows what I'm talking about; if you really want to get to know what a person is really like inside have them work on a car.On a serious note though I think the game is pretty cool and refreshingly different but as someone who works on his own cars I have to say this is more of a puzzle game than a simulator but still intriguing if you're interested in the internal workings of a car; I can see how this game would be super interesting for someone who hasn't much experience working on cars.Maybe I just haven't got far enough into the game yet but the cars seem rather barren and the engine compartment isn't a dizzing array of hoses, pipes and wires like in real life.Also why is oil disposal $100? Maybe it's just where I live where you can dispose of oil for free at any auto parts store or a county waste site, but it's probably just one of those gameplay balancing things.One thing I do like is being able to go on the computer ingame and then finding and ordering parts from fictitious websites. It's not a biggie but a nice touch I think.My only real complaint is the music which is pretty much, so far, nothing but the wub wub wub kind of dubstep.Being a car mechanic themed game I would expect something a little more blue collar like rock or blues but that's okay; I opted to turn the music off and listen to my own music so it's not that big of a deal.One suggestion for the developers: Make a more detailed version of this game in VR with the Vive controllers. That would be awesome!

Posted: March 10, 2016
												Car Mechanic simulator is a TON of fun. I've lost more than a few hours playing this game (a lot of offline hours not counted at time of review here). I'd strongly recommend this to anyone who has an interest in learning about cars, but doesn't have an extra car they can risk working on. Here's a quick list of pros and cons of the game:Pros:- Great concept and parts. You get work with a lot of really deep and interesting parts on a surprising number of different car models.- Great progression. For the most part, the game starts you off with an easy fix (outer tie rods, brake pads, calipers, etc), and then builds up the difficulty by making you diagnose the problem, and giving you the tools and education to make that diagnosis.- Impressive graphics. Nothing stunning, but for a game of this caliber, it's got great visuals for hundreds of different car parts.- GREAT with Steam Controller. Load up a good Config, and have a blast.-Educational. Seriously, this game taught me a lot more about cars than I would've imagined. It won't turn you into a master mechanic, but it may help give you an idea of what's going wrong with a car, and maybe even give you the motivation to look up some How-To videos on youtube.Cons:- Restrictive. The game deals almost exclusively with the engine, suspension, and exhaust, and the only fluid you'll encounter is an oil change. While that's not too bad, I would've loved to see some involvement with a vehicle's AC system. Additionally, it doesn't take into account steering, brake, or transmission fluids, or well-placed oil which is a little disappointing.- Unrealistic. In this game, you can pop off an Outer Tie Rod with a single screw- don't try doing that in real life, or you'll find yourself calling for a tow truck. While I understand the appeal to fun, a lot of parts just have this overwhelming sense of easiness about removing/replacing them.- Occasionally frustrating. The green/yellow/red outlines for parts can be a help, or a big hinderance when trying to figure out what part needs to be removed before the piece you've selected. While it's not a bad system by any means, it's in desperate need of some alternative options. Also, I don't know what car the Maluch was modeled after, but I hope the factory that made it burns down.- Lack of customization. All of your upgrades concern either improving your maintenance speed (why?) or adding OBD/Compression/Electronic testers. You can unlock a paint shop, test path and parking lot, but your garage is never given any real options to make it feel like home.- Lack of endgame. In a perfect world, you'd combine this game and, a decent racing game. While fixing a car, or filling your lot with top-of-the-line beauties is nice, it's hard to get excited when there's not much room to have any fun with them. All this horsepower, and no room to gallop!All in all, CMS2015 is a lot of fun. If you're on the fence, wait until one of it's awesome sales roll around. It's definitely worth $20, and the DLC (aside from the Maluch) are all worth checking out.

Posted: March 24
												This game is a massive improvement to CMS14 in every meaningful way, and will help to quickly fill in the gaps to your car knowledge. As with any simulator, there is only so far that you can go to make it feel like the real thing, but in terms of interactive, consumer-grade media, this is probably the best thing on the market right now.The game can get a little repetitive at times, but I'm sure being an actual car mechanic gets a little repetetive too, particularly if you were to specialize in a limited field (like Japanese import transmissions, etc.). This game allows you to work on all aspects of a car, and for the most part, you can strip the cars down to the bone. The upgrade system is kind of a grind, but overall the pacing feels right. If you start a traditional game, the vehicles will have lists of the parts that need replacing, which can be highlighted on the car and identified easily. Over time, the lists will start to identify fewer and fewer parts, and force you to have to search for them and inspect manually. The projects themselves also become increasingly complicated. This system feels like it's rewarding your learning, and it's an empowering feeling. In general I detest the business model in games nowadays -- especially from major studios/publishers -- that basically forces you to buy 'modules' in the form of DLC that should have been included at launch by default. This game does that, but doesn't feel like you're being robbed either. You may only be interested in learning the SUV/Truck or an old Mini, so in that sense it works and makes sense here. In this setting. it doesn't subtract from the gameplay or force you to purchase the ending/continuation of the story, so I can't knock it too much.In a relatively limited timeframe, you will probably be able to name every single part on a car, regardless of the engine/vehicle type. If that is your goal, you can't miss this one. Can't wait to see what they do with the next iteration.

Posted: October 13, 2016
												Most addicting simulator available.Audio - 7/10 I usually listen to my own music.Video - 9/10Gameplay - 10/10Story - 7/10 You take control of a bodyless camera and are told to repair cars, simple and effective. Once you unlock the auction the "story" ceases to exist. I'd like for more of a background to the player, maybe a rags to riches story? Immersion - 10/10I played and enjoyed the 2014 game but felt the immersion was lacking a bit, but holy hell is this game immersive. I've worked on and around cars for nearly all of my life, my father owned a body shop and would also do engine repairs. I hate to say this but this game makes me feel like I'm in a garage. I say that I hate to say that only because there are obvious video game aspects to the gameplay.This is also the only game where I own all of the DLC. Most DLC in other games feel utterly pointless but I really like that the developer was able to get deals with companies like Masarati, Delorean, and so on. If I stuck the same vanilla cars I probably would have quit playing but thankfully the added items, cars, and features allows for non-stop gaming.I can easily sink 5 hrs into one sitting. This definitely gets a recommendation from me.

Posted: July 4, 2016
												I'm no expert when it comes to cars but this game has got my attention, I bought this game not only to have fun but to learn car parts as well. The game is really fun (seriously), especially if you buy the Performance DLC because you can modify your own car even more like swapping engines! Unfortunately there's no tutorial, at least for the control. You won't be guided what to do to fix the car, you'll be given list of parts that needs to be replaced and that's it (I even search Google Image to find the location of the part xD). If you gain enough XP there will be more challenges, like you need to find the broken parts yourself. Soon you'll get tools like OBD Scanner to help you examine broken parts faster and more easily.---------------------------The game's pretty small though, unlike game like Euro Truck Simulator 2 where you can name you company, hire staff, travel between countries. This game only let you work inside a garage alone, so this game can be boring after you play the game for a while. Well you can test cars in a test track, buy your own personal car, and have a drag race but that's basically it. Even so, to purchase your own car, you need to get a parking lot, which require lots of XP to be able to purchase it.---------------------------You should purchase this game if you're interested in cars, because believe me, you'll be fixing cars all day long and if you're not into it you'll ditch the game right away.
